item.title: Interactive computing overview
item.description: This article introduces the resources on JASMIN available for interactive computing (as opposed to batch computing). It covers:

item.title: Login servers
item.description:
Available login servers  

There are four login servers available to access resources within JASMIN. Users with the jasmin-login access role can access the following servers via SSH .

item.title: Login problems
item.description: Having problems connecting to a host on JASMIN? Details of how to login to JASMIN can be found here, but this article may help to resolve login problems. It provides information for the following issues:

item.title: Graphical linux desktop using NoMachine NX
item.description:
Introduction  

  • This service provides a graphical Linux desktop on JASMIN, ideal for use with graphics-heavy tasks like interactive work with large images.
  • The desktop environment includes a Firefox web browser which can be used to access internal-only web resources.

Using graphical applications over a wide-area network can be very slow, and is not recommended or supported on JASMIN. This service provides a better alternative with graphical desktop within the JASMIN environment itself, rather than on the user’s local machine.

item.title: Scientific analysis servers
item.description:
Intro  

Once you have logged on to one of the login servers you can then ssh to a scientific analysis (sci) server to do your work. The sci servers are not directly accessible outside the firewall of RAL (JASMIN’s host instution) so most users will need to access them via a login server.

item.title: Tenancy Sci Analysis VMs
item.description: This document explains how to access a tenancy-based sci machine. These are normally provisioned by an admin/manager representing a particular community/institution.

item.title: Transfer servers
item.description:
This article lists the JASMIN data transfer servers and provides links to how they can be used.

JASMIN provides specific servers for managing data transfers. These are:

item.title: Creating a virtual environment in the JASMIN Notebooks Service
item.description: Creating a virtual environment is useful to allow a discrete set of extra packages to be installed to meet specific requirements. This allows a user to run multiple environments with different dependencies without conflicts.

item.title: Project-specific servers
item.description:
Deprecated feature documented here to provide information about how to access existing instances. Project-specific servers are no longer provided on request, as most use cases can be satisfied by a tenancy in the JASMIN cloud.

This article introduces the project specific servers. It covers:

item.title: Dask Gateway
item.description:
Introduction  

Dask Gateway  is a service which manages Dask  clusters for users. On JASMIN, it creates a Dask cluster in LOTUS, our batch computing cluster. It automatically creates a Dask for you, scheduling Slurm jobs to create Dask schedulers and workers as appropriate.

item.title: JASMIN Notebooks Service
item.description: The JASMIN Notebooks Service provides access to Jupyter Notebooks  in a web browser.
